channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: London protests: Seven charged and 145 arrested as police appeals continue
item.description: Nine officers were injured and 145 arrested, most of whom police said were right-wing counter-protesters.

item.title: Overseas doctors will remain 'crucial' despite recruitment drive - regulator
item.description: The General Medical Council says efforts to recruit more UK doctors will take years to take effect.

item.title: Retail giants call for more abuse protection for workers
item.description: Dozens of bosses at High Street firms and several MPs are calling for better protection for staff.

item.title: Welfare cuts worth billions planned by ministers
item.description: The changes, affecting hundreds of thousands of people from 2025, would save £4bn in welfare payments.

item.title: Man grabs Greta Thunberg's microphone after pro-Palestinian chants at climate rally
item.description: The stage invader says he "came here for a climate demonstration, not a political view".

item.title: Big Brother's Trish Balusa apologises after historical tweets resurface
item.description: Producers try to work out how an evicted housemate's problematic posts were not flagged before.

item.title: Suella Braverman: Shapps won't back home secretary's language on policing
item.description: He distances himself from the home secretary's language, but says it is "proper" to debate the issue.

item.title: Five US troops die in training air crash in eastern Mediterranean
item.description: The service members died in a helicopter crash in a region where the US has boosted operations.

item.title: Illegal e-bike riders 'goading' officers, police say
item.description: Communities want action on illegal bikes but police are cautious after high-profile deaths.

item.title: Storm Debi: Warning over gale force winds and heavy rain
item.description: The Met Office warns of possible danger to life from flying debris and large waves in coastal areas.

item.title: Tourists 'rethinking their relationship with Earth'
item.description: An increasing number of holidaymakers are picking more environmentally-friendly trips.

item.title: Homeless tents destroyed during Met Police operation
item.description: The force issued a dispersal order and arrested one homeless man on Friday afternoon in Camden.

item.title: Rishi Sunak joins Diwali celebrations in Southampton
item.description: The prime minister attends the celebrations at the Vedic Society Hindu Temple in Southampton.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Suella comes out fighting and pre-Christmas tax cuts
item.description: The papers lead on the home secretary's future, reflect on Armistice Day and ask whether tax cuts are on the way.

item.title: Film: Super Gran hopes to get Peter Rabbit and Paddington-style reboot
item.description: The 1980s children's TV series could be set for a reboot after Welsh scriptwriter wins top accolade.

item.title: Grime Kids: 'We want to inspire young black and ethnic kids'
item.description: The cast of BBC Three drama Grime Kids speak about playing a group of friends who dream of local fame.

item.title: Julius Malema: Why the South African politician touched a nerve in Kenya
item.description: Julius Malema had candid views on Kenya's president but also poses a challenge to the opposition.

item.title: Capturing war-time memories, before it is too late
item.description: Three of the last generation of World War Two veterans share recollections of the deadliest war in history.

item.title: The Northampton shoemaker who caught the Auschwitz commander
item.description: A Northampton leather worker fluent in German was key to capturing a Nazi commander.

item.title: Donald Trump: Legal experts see uphill battle in fraud case
item.description: Two weeks of testimony from Donald Trump and his family has hurt his case, say lawyers watching.

item.title: How area once dubbed 'tent city' cut rough sleeping
item.description: Bringing support services and emergency beds under one roof helps keep people in Milton Keynes off the streets.

item.title: Whitney Wolfe Herd: How the Bumble boss changed the dating scene
item.description: Whitney Wolfe Herd is stepping down as chief executive at the end of the year after nearly a decade.

item.title: Suella Braverman row: Who's scared of Rishi Sunak?
item.description: Suella Braverman may yet be sacked but the PM's handling of her disobedience has dented his authority.

item.title: The Papers: Sacking calls grow and 'dignity and dishonour'
item.description: The papers lead on Saturday’s Armistice Day demonstrators clashing with police.

item.title: China's matchmaking mums have a powerful ally: The Party
item.description: Chinese leaders add to parental pressure, urging young Chinese to marry and have babies.

item.title: Amoako Boafo - the Ghanaian artist who has exhibited in space
item.description: The rags to riches story of Amoako Boafo, whose portraits of black subjects now command mega prices.

item.title: Welcome to Wrexham, Philadelphia and the Welsh language
item.description: From place names to police badges and even a St Asaph church, Pennsylvania has strong Welsh links.

item.title: Cricket World Cup 2023: 'England found a blueprint to avoid falling apart'
item.description: England's World Cup campaign was shrouded with confusion but they found a blueprint that helped them avoid falling apart like previous sides.

item.title: I'm a Celebrity 2023: The rumoured line-up from Nigel Farage to Jamie Lynn Spears
item.description: Politician Nigel Farage and actress Jamie-Lynn Spears are reportedly lined up to take part.

item.title: Life-support withdrawn from critically ill baby Indi Gregory
item.description: Christian Concern says eight-month-old Indi Gregory has been moved to a hospice.

item.title: Diwali 2023: What you need to know about the festival of light
item.description: It's about the triumph of good over evil, but also a chance for family and friends to come together.

item.title: Remembrance Day: King Charles leads wreath-laying on Whitehall
item.description: King Charles III lays the first wreath at London's Cenotaph to remember those who have died in conflict.

item.title: Iceland volcano: Emergency declared over volcano Fagradalsfjall eruption concerns
item.description: Thousands are asked to evacuate from a town over fears magma has spread underground.

item.title: Escaped circus lion roams around Italian town before capture
item.description: Video shows the big cat wandering along a residential street before it is captured.

item.title: Peter Nygard: Fashion mogul guilty of sex assaults
item.description: The 82-year-old is still facing a trial in Montreal and extradition to the US.

item.title: ATP Finals 2023 results: Novak Djokovic ends year as world number one after beating Holger Rune
item.description: Novak Djokovic ends the year as world number one for a record eighth time after beating Holger Rune at the ATP Finals in Italy.

item.title: Middlesbrough Council defends charging landlord £43,000
item.description: Gareth Stobart says the council is charging over £800 per flat in a block of student accommodation.

item.title: Chelsea 4-4 Manchester City: Cole Palmer hits late penalty to deny former club victory
item.description: Cole Palmer scores injury-time penalty against former club Manchester City as Chelsea snatch a thrilling Premier League draw at Stamford Bridge.

item.title: French police thwart €600,000 champagne heist
item.description: Thieves steal two truckloads of expensive bubbly but the loot is recovered after a high-speed chase.

item.title: 'Remarkable' Titanic menu sells for £84,000 at Wiltshire auction
item.description: Hundreds of items from the RMS Titanic went up for auction on Saturday.

item.title: Ofcom will not tell GB News to stop hiring politicians
item.description: The media watchdog's chairman says it is not his job to tell broadcasters who to hire.

item.title: Spain's conservatives rally against deal with Catalan separatists
item.description: Protests denounce a deal with Catalan separatists aimed at securing a new term for the Socialist PM.

item.title: Should some place names be written only in Welsh?
item.description: Some argue that if the Welsh and the English spelling is only slightly different - why have both?

item.title: NHS board named in Glasgow hospital corporate homicide probe
item.description: It follows the deaths of four patients at the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital campus in Glasgow.

item.title: French march against antisemitism shakes up far right and far left
item.description: Far-right leader Marine Le Pen takes part, alongside major parties but the far left refuses.

item.title: Skating on a once-in-a-decade 'ice window' in Alaska
item.description: Footage shows an ice rescue instructor skating on a rare window of ice in Alaska's Alpine lakes.

item.title: NWSL final: Megan Rapinoe forced to leave farewell game early due to Achilles injury
item.description: Megan Rapinoe suffers a painful end to her football career as the American star is forced to leave the pitch just three minutes into her farewell game.

item.title: Chelsea 4-4 Manchester City: Premier League at its best? A game too good to have a winner?
item.description: Chelsea's 4-4 draw with Manchester City "had everything" - but where does it rank among the Premier League's best-ever games?

item.title: Liverpool 3-0 Brentford: Reds close the gap as Jurgen Klopp reminded of his roots
item.description: Liverpool boss was taken back to his early days of his coaching career as the Reds beat Brentford to close the gap on Premier League leaders Manchester City.

item.title: Leicester 2-6 Arsenal: 'Supremely clinical' Gunners playing 'the Arsenal way' in comeback win
item.description: As comebacks go, Arsenal's recovery to thrash Leicester 6-2 was pretty incredible - is it the start of something special for Jonas Eidevall's side?

item.title: Billie Jean King Cup: Late replacement Harriet Dart wins to give GB play-off victory
item.description: Late replacement Harriet Dart beats Caijsa Hennemann to give Great Britain a 3-1 victory in their Billie Jean King Cup play-off against Sweden.

item.title: Match of the Day 2: How Cole Palmer created 'magnificent' Chelsea impact
item.description: Match of the Day 2-s Alan Shearer, Ian Wright and Mark Chapman analyse how ex-Manchester City player Cole Palmer has made an impact at Chelsea.

item.title: Garth Crooks' Team of the Week: Alisson, Saliba, McGinn, Palmer and more feature in Premier League's best
item.description: Which Premier League players impressed our football pundit Garth Crooks enough to make his latest Team of the Week?

item.title: Israel's president denies it is striking Gaza's Al-Shifa hospital
item.description: Isaac Herzog told the BBC "everything is operating" at Al-Shifa, despite reports of no power.

item.title: In Gaza, fleeing refugees face hunger and disease: 'We are in the Dark Ages’
item.description: Hundreds of thousands who fled bombs are now washing in polluted seawater and sleeping in packed tents.

item.title: Gaza casualties: 'Most of the children in my family photo are dead'
item.description: Palestinians abroad tell the BBC multiple generations of their families were killed in Gaza air strikes.

item.title: Hamas hostages: The faces of those taken from Israel to Gaza
item.description: From elderly grandparents to young children, these are the people known to have been taken captive.

item.title: Weeks into the war, how much closer is Israel to its goal?
item.description: Israel wants to destroy Hamas, but there are questions over whether that is achievable.

item.title: Jewish fears as German support for Israel is challenged on streets
item.description: As fighting continues between Israel and Hamas, social discord is emerging in Germany.

item.title: 'Her life is painkillers' - The Gaza children ravaged by war
item.description: More than 26,000 Gazans have been wounded since war erupted, many of them left with life-changing injuries.

item.title: One fled Gaza City, one stayed - what became of Farida and Khalid?
item.description: Teacher Farida and Khalid, a medical supplier, describe life in Gaza, besieged and under attack.

item.title: Israel sees 'sign of life' in Gaza hostage video
item.description: Palestinian Islamic Jihad posts videos of two Gaza hostages, but Israel fears "psychological terror".

item.title: Divided communities in the occupied West Bank
item.description: Arabs and Jews living in the territory say the 7 October attacks have deepened distrust.

item.title: US says Israel to begin daily four-hour military pauses in Gaza
item.description: However Israel stressed the "localised and pinpoint measures" would "not detract from the fighting".

item.title: Israel-Gaza war: Dead bodies and tanks on road south as people flee
item.description: BBC Verify has been looking at video, listening to eyewitnesses and analysing satellite images.

item.title: 'We walked into a wasteland' - BBC's Jeremy Bowen in Gaza with Israeli forces
item.description: IDF soldiers showed the BBC what they called a Hamas weapons factory, under a home where children lived.

item.title: Gazan tells BBC about most terrifying call of his life
item.description: An extraordinary warning call to a Palestinian dentist starts the panicked evacuation of a Gazan neighbourhood.

item.title: UK accused of 'whitewash' after Chevening scholar feared killed in Gaza
item.description: Dr Maisara Al Rayyes's family is searching for him under a building destroyed in an Israeli strike.

item.title: Hamas hostages: Israeli mothers recall their children being kidnapped by Hamas
item.description: Renana Jacob says the last time she spoke to her son, he was telling attackers he was "too young" to be taken.

item.title: Five arrested after pro-Palestinian protest at Scottish Parliament
item.description: Police set up a cordon after activists occupied an area near the front entrance of Holyrood.

item.title: British nationals and dependents stopped from leaving Gaza with families
item.description: Two men say Egypt sent them back to a warzone after they waited for days at the Rafah crossing.

item.title: Hezbollah warns of regional war if Gaza bombing goes on
item.description: The BBC's Orla Guerin spoke with Sheikh Naim Qassem, second-in-command of the Lebanese Shia Islamist group.

item.title: US's only Palestinian-American Congresswoman censured over comments
item.description: Michigan Democrat defends pro-Palestinian "river to sea" chant as an "aspirational call for freedom".

item.title: Jewish students at UK universities 'deeply anxious', union warns
item.description: Both antisemitic and islamophobic abuse is rising at universities, experts tell the BBC.

item.title: Israel-Gaza war: Civilians leave northern Gaza along evacuation corridor
item.description: For several hours, hundreds of people were on the move, some on carts pulled by donkeys but most on foot.

item.title: The writers who reached out across the divide
item.description: An Israeli and Palestinian set up a group to share experiences of life in Gaza. And then the war broke out.

item.title: How to get a job: Six expert tips for finding work
item.description: There are 10m people out of work in the UK, so if you're searching for a job you're not alone. Here are some tips on how to get started.

item.title: Five ways to save money on your packed lunch
item.description: Grabbing food on the go can be expensive so here are some top tips on making savings at lunchtime.

item.title: When should I turn the heating on?
item.description: As it gets colder here are some tips to help you stay warm while trying to keep your energy bills down.

item.title: Autumn Statement 2023: When is it and how will it affect me?
item.description: Chancellor Jeremy Hunt is set to unveil the government's tax and spending plans.

item.title: How to save money even when the budget is tight
item.description: The interest paid on savings is better than anything seen for years, so how can you save when bills are rising?
